littlefish.core.utilities module¶

littlefish.core.utilities.array_nor(arr)[source]¶
littlefish.core.utilities.check_arithmetic_progression(seq)[source]¶

check a 1-d list of numbers is arithmetic progression sequence

:return bool

littlefish.core.utilities.check_binary_2d_array(array)[source]¶

check if an array is 2 dimensional and _dtype is int and only contains 0s and 1s

littlefish.core.utilities.check_df_index(df)[source]¶

check if the indices of a pandas dataframe is a series in an ascending order with increment as 1 and starts at 0

Returns:bool
littlefish.core.utilities.check_monotonicity(arr, direction=’increasing’)[source]¶

check monotonicity of a 1-d array, usually a time series

Parameters:
  • arr – input array, should be 1 dimensional
  • direction – ‘increasing’, ‘decreasing’, ‘non-increasing’, ‘non-decreasing’
Returns:

True or False
littlefish.core.utilities.decode(str_like, code=’UTF-8’)[source]¶

if a string like object is actually a ‘bytes’ type, decode it by ‘UTF-8’, and return the string. This is to deal with the hdf5 string format madness.

Parameters:
  • str_like –
  • code –
Returns:

str
littlefish.core.utilities.discreat_crosscorrelation(ts_trigger, ts_reference, t_range=(-10.0, 20.0), bin_width=1.0)[source]¶

generate crosscorrelogram between two timestamp train

Parameters:
  • ts_trigger – the triggering time stamps, 1d array, monotonically increasing
  • ts_reference – the reference time stamps, 1d array, monotonically increasing
  • t_range – para-trigger time range, tuple with two floats
  • bin_with – duration of a single bin
Returns:

crosscorrelogram of counts, 1-d array, int t_axis, time axis of crosscorrelogram, 1-d array, float
littlefish.core.utilities.get_random_number(distribution, shape)[source]¶

get a random number from given distribution

Parameters:
  • distribution – tuple in the format, (distribution type, parameter1, parameter2, …) supported: (‘flat’, mean, range), (‘gaussian, mean, sigma), (‘exponential’, mean)
  • shape – output shape
Returns:

a random number
littlefish.core.utilities.int2str(num, length=None)[source]¶

generate a string representation for a integer with a given length

Parameters:
  • num – input number
  • length – length of the string
Returns:

string represetation of the integer
littlefish.core.utilities.is_integer(var)[source]¶
littlefish.core.utilities.plot_mask(mask, plot_axis=None, color=’#ff0000’, closing_iteration=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

plot mask (ROI) borders by using pyplot.contour function. all the 0s and Nans in the input mask will be considered as background, and non-zero, non-nan pixel will be considered in ROI.

littlefish.core.utilities.plot_mask_borders(mask, plot_axis=None, color=’#ff0000’, border_width=2, closing_iteration=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

plot mask (ROI) borders by using pyplot.contour function. all the 0s and Nans in the input mask will be considered as background, and non-zero, non-nan pixel will be considered in ROI.

littlefish.core.utilities.plot_spike_ticks(spike_history, y=0.0, plot_axis=None, color=’#ff0000’, **kwargs)[source]¶

plot spike ticks as separate dots

Parameters:
  • spike_history – list of ints, spike timestamps on time unit axis
  • y – float, vertical locations of spike line
  • plot_axis – plotting axis, matplotlib.pyplot.axis object
  • color – plotting color
  • kwargs – other inputs to matplotlib.pyplot.plot function
Returns:

plot_axis
littlefish.core.utilities.short(str)[source]¶

retrun abbreviation of a string
